div.p: so we are from civis analytics we
brought our whole squad but we're here
today to talk to you about is a project
we worked on with an organization in the
city of New York we were trying to do
with them is help figure out where
benefits and weren't taking advantage of
them so we'll dive into that a little
bit we can also reintroduce ourselves my
name is Kelly Kraft I'm a senior applied
data scientist at civis I'm at Victory
Kumar and applied data scientist at
service thanks and I'm Ola to Chaves
crime also an applied data scientist
thank you and yeah so a little bit about
us and the organization we were working
with so civis was formed out of the
Obama 2012 analytics department so we
worked on the reelect campaign we had a
big analytics team about 50 people we
kind of worked across the campaign to
try to figure out ways where we could
influence the strategy and make sure
that we were targeting the right voters
and providing the right messages the
right people and saving money where we
could by placing ads correctly and that
sort of thing
and so then our CEO and Founder as well
as some of our early members of civics
were all on the Obama analytics team in
2012 but we've moved on from politics
we're still doing politics but we're
also trying to apply our data science
methods and products across other
industries so nonprofit groups and
government we're working with the media
team of the 2020 census with the city of
New York we also have some corporate
clients so trying to figure out ways
that we can apply what we've learned in
the campaign and since then to help
these organizations operate more
efficiently for this project
specifically we were working with the
Robin Hood Foundation which is a really
large anti-poverty organization in New
York City so what they do is they want
to find organizations that are working
on the ground to help lift people out of
poverty so they provide grants to these
groups on the ground and last in the
last year they invested over 130 million
dollars in the city of New York so what
they came to us for our help with is
that they wanted to figure out where
people were eligible for the Earned
Income Tax Credit and where people were
eligible for food stamps and weren't
taking advantage of those opportunities
so snap in the earned income tax credit
are actually two of the most effective
anti-poverty programs in the United
States but there is a gap of people who
are eligible but aren't participating so
that's about 20% of those folks so that
was the goal for this project was to

p.span: figure out where the participation gaps

div.p: were in the city of New York understand
who those eligible non-participating
individuals are and then find a way to
connect them with robin hood and the
organizations on the ground so there's a
couple of challenges that we'll talk a
little bit about but this is a group of
people that's hard to find data about so
you know we know who we know roughly the
number of people who participate in
these programs and we know based on
criteria who should be eligible but we
don't have a list of like these
participating families we don't have a
list of these eligible and participating
individuals and a lot of the thing below
the data sources we were working with
which we'll talk about we're at a
different level so we were looking at
specific neighborhoods in New York but
we had access to data that was maybe
state level or you know we could look at
national trends but we had to kind of
figure out a way to apply that to a
geography that would be useful for robin
hood so we combine a difference at a
large set of tools and data sources to
answer this question to calculate and
figure out where people are eligible but
not participating in the program we
started by taking participation data
that the IRS releases for the Earned
Income Tax Credit and that one of Robin
Hood's partner foundations in New York
we combine that with eligibility data to
estimate the overall size of the
eligible population we use data that the
census releases publicly about American
communities in a survey called the
American Community Survey there we also
rolled in a lot of New York City
specific data so things like 303 1 1
calls locations of benefit centers and
things like that to help sharpen our
inference in these particular
neighborhoods we were able to combine a
lot of these in a platform a data
modeling and use platform that we
develop and use internally and that
allowed us to combine sort data sources
at different levels and funnel it
through different stages of our workflow
so once we collected our data sources we
came up with a series of direct
estimates for non-participation for
these different programs and
and we did that by taking these
eligibility requirements for each
program and applying them directly to
data that the census releases about
these communities we did that in our and
we scripted a little bit of that with
our platform as well so what this gave
us was a starting point an estimate of
what we thought of where we thought the
participation gaps were in New York City
but we thought we could do one better
than just that direct estimate and to
incorporate a lot of the information
about New York City specifically we
built in a second modeling step to
refine those estimates based on data
outside the American Community Survey
that was more specific to New York City
and that's where our platform really
helped us out in terms of building a
series of models quality control for
these models and things like that that
allowed us to focus more on the
conceptual questions and structuring the
entire workflow in a way that was
helpful to our client so let's talk a
little bit about how we read eligibility
criteria out of the census and came up
with our direct estimates for simplicity
we'll focus on the Earned Income Tax
Credit though our process for snap food
stamps is similar to this so the ACS is
this large survey that the census
administers every year to about 1% of
the US population it gives us detailed
information about people and the
households that they lived in the two
catches are first the data is anonymized
so as Kelly was saying it's not tied to
specific people or specific households
in a way that you can really so it's
released with these random IDs attached
to these records and it's released at a
geographic level called the public use
microdata area or Puma so in addition to
being majestic beasts Pumas are
geographies that contain at least a
hundred thousand people they're built
from census tracts and their statistical
geographies that the census uses to
maintain consistency with its sampling
and survey procedures year over year so
to give you an idea of what Pumas look
like pretty sure we are currently in
this Puma in Chicago who must tend to
map to groups of neighborhoods so the
Puma we're in is a combination of the
loop South Loop and River north so it's
a combination of neighborhoods and that
tends to apply for other parts of the
city as well one of these difficult
pieces then
taking data that's released at this
geography and combining with data that's
released at zip code levels at County
levels when all those pieces might not
align entirely so this is what ACS data
looks like this is the information we
have about people that live in each Puma
we have a serial number that ties people
to specific households and then we have
detailed information that people
reported to the Census Bureau including
their age different types of income some
information about how they're related to
each other and so on you don't need to
focus on the specifics of this
information we just wanted to give you
an idea of the structure of the data
we're working with so a ITC eligibility
depends on a series of facts about you
and your family depends on your income
depends on how many whether you're
married depends on whether you have kids
and a few other things so what we do to
read this information out of the ACS is
we split the data into households as
identified by a household flag in the
data and then we identify sub units
within each household people we think
are married to each other who we think
their kids are their total income for
each unit and so on so we directly apply
program logic to these households and
say what is the income how many kids
does this married couple have are they
eligible for the the Earned Income Tax
Credit the catch is the EITC eligibility
criteria are very detailed and the ACS
does not ask about information at that
level of detail so for example you for
someone to be your qualifying child for
the Earned Income Tax Credit they have
to be either a related to you by blood
or by legal ties and that's not
necessarily what people will report to
the census that's not perfectly captured
information there in the American
Community Survey so what we've shown you
here is that from the get-go if we're
trying to read eligibility out of the
American Community Survey we're not
going to get all the information we need
and this is one of our motivations for
building modeled estimates on top of our
direct estimates is that we think direct
estimates can't do the job perfectly and
we can supplement them and improve them
by incorporating other pieces of

p.span: information so the other thing that we

div.p: do is we try to validate our model our
direct estimates against external data
sources where possible so one of the
things that we do to calculate a EITC
eligibility is calculate the adjusted
gross income for each family member your
adjusted gross income is a combination
of different income types depends on
like 15 lines of your 1040 form and what
we do is we compare the average income
that people make in our model from the
ACS what data that's released by the IRS
at the zip code level so we say among
three key income brackets where people
could be eligible for these programs
what does our average person make
compared to the average filer that the
IRS releases and we find that in general
over years for our model we're able to
track income pretty well for people who
make twenty four to seventy four
thousand dollars if you look at these
points they line up at about 95 percent
so the people in our model are earning
slightly less than the typical person in
the that the IRS reports but we don't
think it's a large enough amount to
throw our estimates off significantly
well we do notice though is that our
estimates are noisy but roughly in the
right ballpark for people who earn one
dollar to twenty four thousand dollars
so on the bottom income bracket there's
a lot of noise and reported income to
the ACS and we think there are a couple
of other factors going into this as well
but basically what this diagnostic told
us is that our income model while good
is far from perfect and we can probably
improve these estimates by adding a
modeling step right so this is our
second motivation for modeling it's not
just that the criteria are hard to read
but our best reading of the criteria
isn't where we want it to be so pass the
things to Ola thanks so Mike advic
mentioned our next step with modeling
and basically we use the features that
we had collected from public sources as
well as from these open data sources in
New York City open data portal and
partners of the Robin Hood Foundation to
construct a modeling file where the
dependent variable the thing that we
were interested in predicting was that
direct estimate of participation so that
estimate was basically just the ratio of
the number of people that we had from
reported sources participating in a
given program or tax units in the case
of EITC
/ the number of families or individuals
that we estimated were eligible from the
ACS and we fed a model on top of that to
basically improve our estimates and
bring in a lot of this additional data
we did this in two steps so our first
step was a lasso model so a regularized
linear regression where we were trying
predictive for this particular problem

p.span: and because we had such rich data from

div.p: our commercial data from these
additional data sources that we brought
in we weren't sure exactly which of
those hundreds of features would be most
predictive and we didn't want to overfit
after we had selected features using
that lasso model we put a fit a
multi-level bayesian model to actually
come up with our ultimate participation
rates and what this allowed us to do is
incorporate changes that were happening
at the tract level at the Puma level and
over four years of time in our data to
precise less variable estimates of what
we thought the actual non-participation
was and in practice this turned out to
do the thing that we had hoped it would
which is that it brought our most
extreme point estimates down closer to
the median and we think that is both an
indication of adjusting for some of
those errors in the ACS but also
controlling for the fact that some of
those geographies were really small and
there was just inherently a lot of noise
in the survey estimates so we handed
Robin Hood a series of Puma level
estimates of communities in New York
where they should target their outreach
but New York City is about 55 Pumas
total so it still wasn't add a level of
granularity where they could identify
the subway stops or particular
intersections where they should be doing
outreach and they were interested really
in doing direct canvassing to
individuals working with partner
organizations in the community and
really getting as granular as possible
into specific ethnic communities or you
know immigrant communities reaching out
to people through different channels and
so a question that they had for us at
this stage was can we drill all the way
down to the track level which would get
us into you know several thousand
observations of the city of New York as
opposed to fifty five and this is a
challenge for us because our the data
that we have
of the administrative data about
participation really came in at the Puma
level or had been rolled up to the Puma
level and we didn't have a direct model
way of getting at track level
information we couldn't get a CS
eligibility as a track level so we had
to do some creative thinking here and we
tried a bunch of things in consultation
with our some of the data scientists at
our company and we ended up building a
track level model where our Puma so our
higher level of demographic estimates
were the dependent variable and then we
used track level variables as the
explanatory variables and this was the
approach that came up with estimates
that were similar to our promo level
estimates but still had what we thought
was a plausible level variation in a way
that we thought would help the Robin
Hood Foundation better target their
outreach in addition to varying kind of
what was the level of granularity that
we modeled we also tested out different
algorithm types so linear tree based
ensemble methods whether we apply to
transformation to the dependent variable
and then whether we capped the features
that went into the model at some
proportion of what we observed at the
track level so here's an example of some
of the diagnostic plots that we made
these are all different representations
of Bushwick which was one of the Pumas
that we thought was a high target for
EITC and we're looking at what is the
relative density of non-participation
according to our different modeling
approaches and so this one in the bottom
right hand corner was the one that we
ultimately selected which was the tract
based tract level model which was you
know it had the trade-off of both
providing additional variance that we
thought was helpful also not introducing
a lot of noise into the problem that
would have been distracting and this is
an example of how we communicated that
information so we're looking at Bushwick
again and we flagged particular tracts
or we thought there was especially high
non-participation
as well as particular you know stations
and social service organizations in
those tracts that the Robin Hood
Foundation could begin to do outreach to
and you know one thing that is kind of
reassuring here is you see the bottom
right-hand green corner that's actually
a cemetery so totally make sense that we
wouldn't see non-participation there
cool so to kind of zoom out we've been
talking about a ITC but we presented
results to Robinhood for both a ITC and
for snap this is kind of like how we
present it to them but what we found was
that 89% of eligible people receive the
EITC in 2013 and 76% of eligible
eligible people received snap in 2014 we
use different years 2013 and 2014
because that was the participation data
that we had available to us from their
partner organizations so we use the
corresponding ACS data for those years
but we thought it would give a good idea
of like the trends of participation
there so we expected more people who
were eligible to take advantage of the
EITC and slightly less of people who
were eligible for snap to take advantage
of those benefits and we have theories
on why but the EITC participation gap we
found was closely associated with an
area's economic condition so we ran
these models when we did the direct
estimates the variables that we picked
up and we were building our model were
things like vacant housing units like
availability public housing so kind of
like some indicators of the economic
condition of that area so we didn't
actually find significant differences
between different ethnic groups among
different neighborhoods so the areas
that we recommended that Robinhood
consist conduct their outreach were just
places that had a high density of these
non participating eligible individuals
so we just gave them a rank order list
of here the neighborhoods where we think
you would have the most impact if you
walked up to someone on the street you
have a higher chance of that person
being eligible for the EITC but not
taking advantage of it so some of those
neighborhoods are highlighted here the
one on the very bottom this one is
Staten Island which is actually it was
kind of an interesting finding because
Sutton Island in general is like a
higher has a higher median income than
the rest of some of these areas that
we've highlighted in New York but we had
a chance to present to some of their
partner organizations so groups that are
actually doing this outreach on the
ground and we got some like positive
feedback from the folks in Staten Island
we're saying like we actually really
it's like makes sense to us so we got
some good validation there and when we
go to talk about snap we have some
slightly more interesting findings not
more interesting but there's more to
talk about so we found that the
participation gap for snap
was greater in areas with significant
ethnic communities where English isn't
the only language spoken and so we've
some theories there that you know the
eligibility for the application process
for a snap is much different than it is
for ehe CTC you do when you file your

separate location recertification is
much more difficult so we figure there's
some sort of language barrier there

Flushing Queens as a possible place for
